keywords.value: New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal
keywords.name: organizations

lead_paragraph: An increase of up to 9.6 percent, which would affect mostly older tenants, results from a state formula that differs from factors New York City’s rent board used in freezing stabilized rents.

headline.print_headline: A Proposed Rent Increase Stirs Outrage
headline.main: Facing Increase, Rent-Controlled Tenants Complain of Being Singled Out

snippet: An increase of up to 9.6 percent, which would affect mostly older tenants, results from a state formula that differs from factors New York City’s rent board used in freezing stabilized rents.
abstract: New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal proposal to increase rent by 9.6% over two-year period for New York City tenants in rent-controlled apartments triggers outrage; tenants complain they are being singled out, but landlords argue that system used by state housing agency to calculate increases, which differs from New York City Rent Guidelines Board, is more fair.
